prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As described in the Scientific Justification, our goal is measuring the radio flux at band 4 and band 7 for determining the spectral index. We describe the key points according to the proposer's guide.
(1) Sensitivity (i) Source flux The minimum flux density is given when the transition locates at the highest frequency of previous VLBI data (dashed lines in Fig. 3 in the Scientific Justification). We require the image sensitivity to detect this minimum source flux with SNR of 20 and 10 for bands 4 and 7, respectively, in order to make the flux error due to the thermal noise less significant as compared to the flux calibration error (5% and 10% in bands 4 and 7, respectively, proposer's guide). On-source time of 2-min estimated in OT surely can achieve this sensitivity with SNR higher than 20 and 10 for bands 4 and 7, respectively.
(ii) Spatial resolution Though the sub-arcmin-scale structure of target sources is point-like in the NVSS image at 1.4 GHz, target sources might have bright knots in kpc scale similarly to other blazar sources. Thus, high resolution (< 1") is necessary to extract the emission only from the core. Proposed observations achieve this requirement.
(2) Imaging The source structure is expected to be simple, consisting of dominant point-like radio core and possibly some faint point- or Gaussian-like knot features. Since our aim is to measure the flux of the radio core in each source. The snap-shot image is enough for our goal.
(3) Correlator setup Accurate measurement of the radio flux is necessary for this observation. To minimize the spectral index error caused by the flux calibration error, we request 4 spws with largest bandwidth for both two bands. We confirmed that the spectral index determination with an accuracy of <0.15 can be achieved with this frequency settings, from the Monte Carlo simulation assuming the flux calibration error in proposer's guide (5% and 10 % in bands 4 and 7, respectively).
(4) Calibration We adopt standard calibration and not require additional calibrations and/or to use specific sources.
(5) Bandpass accuracy Since our aim is to measure the continuum flux, there is no requirement about spectral response accuracies.
(6) Scheduling/time constraints Sequential observation in two bands within 1 day is necessary for each source, since blazars are usually time variable within days-weeks at mm/sub-mm wavelengths.
(7) Date rate: Our data rate does not exceed the expected average of 6 MB/s
(8) Special constraints on standard observing modes There is no constraint on standard observing modes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe continuum spectrum of five extreme TeV blazars, which are unique probe to study enigmatic extragalactic background light (EBL), for the first time in mm/sub-mm regimes at two frequencies. The goal of this study is to investigate whether their relativistic jets are optically thin at mm wavelengths.
Our preparatory study with ALMA shows optically thin mm-spectrum in most normal blazars, contrary to the most accepted "one-zone SED model" predicting their relativistic jets are optically thick in mm regime. In addition, our study with VLBI does not favor it also for extreme TeV blazars.
If mm emission is optically thin in also extreme TeV blazars, it requires alternative models such as the structured jet model where both of high-energy emission and mm emission can come from the jet base. It will not only give a new picture of jets in blazars, but also affect studies on EBL based on SED models.
These sources are faint for other radio interferometers. Furthermore, sequential observation in two bands is necessary for this proposal, since blazars are usually variable within days-weeks at mm/sub-mm wavelengths. Only ALMA cycle-2 can perform proposed observations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00796.S、Mm/submm Continuum Spectrum of BL Lacs in the Close Vicinity of the Central Engine、PI:H.Nagai

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
